# How do we use probabilities?

## How do we manage climate risks?

::: {.incremental}
1. Reduce emissions to prevent future climate change ("mitigation")
1. Real-time monitoring and forecasting
1. Building codes and design standards
1. Insurance
1. ...
:::

## Sizing a stormwater pipe

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="60%"}
::: {.incremental}
1. Rainfall-runoff model
    - rational method: $Q= C i A$ where $i$ is rainfall intensity, $A$ is area, and $C$ is runoff coefficient
1. Common standard: $\Pr \left\{i > i^* \right\} = 1/T$
    - Annual probability that $i > i^*$ is $1/T$
1. Size your culvert to handle $Q^* = Ci^*A$
1. Requires knowing $p(i)$!
    - Probability distribution of $i$
:::
::::
:::: {.column width="40%"}

## Floodplain mapping in a riverine system

::::: {.columns}
:::: {.column width="60%"}
::: {.notes}
This is a moderately simplified workflow
:::

::: {.incremental}
1. Estimate the 99th percentile (100 year *return level*) of *annual maximum* streamflows $Q$
1. Use a hydraulic model to model where the water goes
1. Requires knowing $p(Q)$
:::

## Index insurance pricing

::: {.incremental}

1. Index insurance: if some index $I$ is above a threshold $I^*$, pay out $X$
    - Total rainfall in a season, area flooded, etc
1. Let $p^* = \Pr \left\{I > I^* \right\}$ is the probability of a payout
1. Naive pricing uses a point estimate of $p^*$: $\frac{R}{X} = \mathbb{E} \left[ p^* \right]$
1. Risk pricing accounts for uncertainty in estimating $p^*$: $\frac{R}{X} = \mathbb{E}[p^*] + \lambda \mathbb{V}^{1/2}[p^*]$
    - Requires knowing $p(p*)$!

:::

## Social cost of carbon

A chain of *conditional probabilities*:

::: {.incremental}
1. $p \left( CO_2 \, \mid \, \text{policy} \right)$
1. $p \left( T \, \mid \, CO_2 \right)$ (*climate sensitivty*)
1. $p \left( \text{local hazard} \, \mid \, T \right)$
1. $p \left( \text{damages} \, \mid \, \text{local hazard} \right)$
:::

. . .

::: {.callout-note}
## Important point

Choices of *which* damages to value (and *to whom*) matters a lot [@errickson_methane:2021]!
:::

## Caveat

This is not to neglect the importance of *epistemic* or *deep* uncertainties whose probability distributions cannot be *objectively* determined.

## Problem statement:

> You are have been comissioned by a small coastal community to quantify the probability distribution of storm surge heights at their location.
This knowledge will help them identify properties at risk of flooding, update zoning codes, and plan for future development.
